summary: human infection with avian influenza A (H7N9) was first identified on march 31, 2013 in china. out of the total number of 134 cases confirmed from March to September 2013 in china, Zhejiang Province saw the greatest number (46 cases) 134 cases of human infection with avian influenza A (H7N9) were identified in 12 provinces. from march to September 2013, 134 cases were identified in 12 provinces. the number of confirmed cases in Hangzhou, the capital city of Zhejiang Province, was the largest. the CDC used 2 accounts, named China Health Education and Zhejiang Health Education, to disseminate information about behaviors to prevent respiratory communicable diseases. inaccurate information and negative attitudes toward emerging communicable diseases may lead to unnecessary concerns, rumors, social chaos, and even excessive panic. CDC conducted cross-sectional and closed survey among mobile phone users in Zhejiang province. a total of 500,000 users from the 5 examined regions in the database of China Unicom were selected. participants' personal information was kept confidential and stored at China Unicom. survey questionnaire was designed by the Zhejiang CDC. participants answered questions about their attitudes toward H7N9. the questionnaire was executed through a mobile internet application platform. answers of 'yes' and 'unclear' were coded into the high-KAP category. answers of 'highly influenced' and'moderately influenced' were coded into the other category. for questions about how one’s daily life had been influenced by H7N9. participants' personal information was kept confidential and stored at China Unicom. 500,000 users from the 5 examined regions in the database of China Unicom were selected. participants who did not complete the questionnaire were excluded. participants answered sociodemographic questions about age, gender, occupation, and education. the questionnaire was executed through a mobile Internet application platform of China Unicom from April 25 to May 2, 2013. answers of visiting a hospital with occurrence of symptoms were coded into the high-KAP category. answers of self-treatment and no treatment were coded into the low-KAP category. a probability (P) value of less than.05 was considered statistically significant. 8379 of 9105 participants (92.03%) had some knowledge of the symptoms of H7N9 and 6816 (74.86%) had some knowledge of its transmission routes. knowledge of H7N9 differed by region, with Hangzhou having the largest. share of participants who had some knowledge about symptoms and transmission routes of H7N9 (2 8=53.0, P.001) and transmission routes of H7N9 (2 8=53.9, P.001) are shown in Figures 1 and 2. internet users in Zhejiang province knew more about the symptoms of H7N9 than about its transmission routes. this showed that people lacked knowledge of how this new communicable disease was transmitted. this suggests that in the outbreak of a new infectious disease, the government should carry out public health education. study revealed that half of participants washed their hands more frequently. tendency to adopt precautionary behaviors to prevent disease infection was seen in previous studies of other types of influenza viruses, such as H1N1 [14-16] enhancing knowledge about a new infectious disease can be an effective strategy to encourage the adoption of preventive measures. findings implied a plausible association between risk perception and the adoption of preventive practices among females. this may also apply to participants with occupations related to poultry industry. mobile Internet users in 5 regions of Zhejiang Province knew more about the symptoms of H7N9 than about its transmission routes. this showed that people lacked knowledge of how this new communicable disease was transmitted. this suggests that in the outbreak of a new infectious disease, the government should carry out public health education. more than half of participants indicated they worried about contracting H7N9. this may be derived from the increasing amount of media coverage of the epidemic and mortality, lack of knowledge about its transmission routes, and closings of live poultry markets. study revealed half of participants washed their hands more frequently. findings implied a plausible relationship between knowledge and preventive practices among females. this may also apply to participants with occupations related to poultry industry. participants with occupations related to poultry industry were more likely to worry about contracting H7N9 and to report their lives being influenced by H7N9. the results may not be generalizable to other residents who were not mobile Internet users. the self-reported survey design may have led to social desirability bias. this may have led to bias in reported KAP levels.
